ygData.subject: Re: Python NEAT
ygData.msgSnippet: Hi Peter, How is your python implementation going? Took a look at the NetworkX module. It looks very interesting! In my C++ version, I had added variable

Hi Peter,

How is your python implementation going? Took a look at the Netw=
orkX module. It looks very interesting! In my C++ version, I had added vari=
able input/output connections, network within a node and seeding of the ini=
tial population with the required infrastructure updates and a distributed =
processing backend. But what you are doing goes so much farther, that I am =
eager to get a look at it!

Andy

--- In neat@yahoogroups.com, "petar_cherv=
enski" <petar_chervenski@...> wrote:
>
> Hi all, 
> 
> I am almost done wit=
h the basic code and I'll mention some of its features now. I decided to us=
e NetworkX for the genomes, because this module has lots of useful algorith=
ms and allows any python object to be a node and edges can be associated wi=
th anything. This makes the evolution of neural networks a tiny part of wha=
t's really possible. Any graph can be evolved, including undirected graphs =
and nodes/edges containing discrete one-of-N values (integers, lists of pyt=
hon objects, etc). So given that an evaluation function exists for any kind=
 of graph, you can quickly setup evolution. Neural networks are a particula=
r kind of graphs and the package will have built in code necessary to evolv=
e neural networks - the initialization functions, mutators, and a C++ inter=
face to a class that represents the phenotypes. CPPNs support is trivial to=
 make, and given that python functions themselves can be attached to nodes,=
 it's possible to have algorithmic nodes working with more than one variabl=
e and .. well, infinite stuff. OK, I gotta go. Wish me luck debugging. Talk=
 to you soon. :) 
> 
> Peter
> 
> --- In neat@yahoogroups.com, Jan van der =
Lugt <janlugt@> wrote:
> >
> > Hi Peter,
> > 
> > Sound like an ambitious a=
nd noble plan. Good luck coding, I'm looking
> > forward to seeing your res=
ults!
> > 
> > Regards,
> > Jan
> > 
> > On Mon, Mar 14, 2011 at 12:43, pet=
ar_chervenski
> > <petar_chervenski@>wrote:
> > 
> > >
> > >
> > > Hi peopl=
e,
> > >
> > > For about a month I'll be writing a Python implementation of=
 NEAT, which
> > > includes all advances in the recent years, including rtN=
EAT, phased
> > > searching, leaky integrators, HyperNEAT, HyperNEAT with e=
volving substrates,
> > > and novelty search. Coevolution code and visualiz=
ations will be included.
> > > Optimized C++ code for running the NNs too. =
This code will be free and I
> > > promise this will be the best NEAT code =
I can write. No bugs, no meaningless
> > > NNs, etc.
> > >
> > > Peter
> > =
>
> > >  
> > >
> >
>
